No longer will the indiscretions
of Hopkins students be confined to
sleepy Homewood. On Friday, a
Candid Camera Man and his attractive feminine partner invaded the
campus and caught some of the students in their habitual pursuits,
such as sleeping and bridge-playing.
The camera man even found two
(2) members of the College for
Teachers whom he thought fit subjects for camera studies. This column of shots of life on the campuses of schools and colleges throughout the state will begin in the
Baltimore News-Post today. See
who got caught by our local Walter
Winchells!

Robert Henry Levi, latest addition to the Hopkins lacrosse team,
was born in Baltimore on March 27,
1915. He received his primary and
high .school education in this city.
At high school, Baltimore City
College, Bob first showed the makings of a lacrosse player. For four
successive years he played under
the tuelage of City's coach, Herman Epstein. In his last year at,
City Levi captained the lacrosse
team which won the state championship.
Veteran Attackman

As he was preparing to enter
Hopkins with advanced standing,
Levi had to limit his extra-curricular activity to lacrosse. Bob entered the School of Business
Economics this past fall but became
sick with an attack of appendicitis
at the end of the first term.
Despite the fact that he has been
handicapped as a result of an operation, he has made an excellent
showing on the Blue Jay lacrosse
team, having played in every game
of the season. His position on the
varsity is second attack.

SIZE OF PIGSKIN CHANGED
Football For'College Games Next Fall. To Be Smaller
Following the trend of the
times, the national rules committee on the game of football has
announced, through its secretary,
William S. Langford, a change in
the specifications of the football
for the 1934 season, which will decrease the circumference and
make it easier to handle and forward pass.
The short axis circumference
has been reduced from the old
measurement range of 22 by 222
inches to 214 by 21%. No change
was made in the other specifications as to weight, air pressure,
general shape, or the long axis
circumference.

Football being one of the games
with an almost universal appeal,
the sport is spreading to all parts
of the world, and the name of the
game itself is becoming a worldwide word.
The French play "football,"
and Spanish and South American
countries call it "el futbol," which
is near enough. The German "outside" wing man scores a "goal" in
football, he plays for his "team"
and does his training if his club
is playing for a "cup." And the
game itself, as in France, is "football."
Players in France, Germany,
and Italy are all penalized by the
referee if they have committed a
"foul." In fact, no footballer need
worry about being misunderstood
anywhere in the world. "Goal,"
"offside," and "center" are practically universal words today.

The All-Union Soviet of Students, whose headquarters are in
Moscow, has addressed an official
invitation to American students to
attend a special international session of the Moscow University
Summer School, beginning July 21.
The invitation was sent to the Institute of International Education
2 West 45th Street, New York.
The Summer School, under the
auspices of the Anglo-American Institute of the First Moscow University, will last six weeks. Lectures and instruction will be in
English, and will be given by a faculty of the foremost Soviet professors and specialists.
The purpose of the school is to
afford visiting students a clear conception of Soviet achievements in
cultural and scientific fields since
the 1917 revolution. Visitors will
be offered a wide program of social,
cultural and sp' ort activities

Club's prize for having done the
most in the field of science in the

to award the prize in the field of
literature to Dr. Paul M. Wheeler,
instructor in English in the College
of Arts and Sciences.
The prizes, which consist of
medals of honor, are awarded each
year by the Baltimore Advertising
Club to Baltimore, men who have
made outstanding contributions in
their fields .

Opposes Class Dues

The inefficiency of the Interfraternity Board was scored heavily
and the necessity for a clear and
potent interfraternity agreement
was, emphasized. The social functions of the classes, Feise argued,
may be well taken care of through
the other campus activities and thus
relieve the necessity for class dues.
Coucluding, he advised redistribution of teaching duties in the cases
of several professors whose effectiveness, he claims, is hampered by
their present schedules. He further suggested the need for improvment as indicated by recent
criticism of professors advanced by
the NEWS-LETTER, both editorially
and in the article, "Top-Heavy
Hopkins". He also asked that seniors be allowed to use the stacks.
Want Group Consciousness

‘Feise's paper, members of 0. D.
K. said, was selected because of its
clarity, comprehensiveness, and the
practicability of the ideas set forth.
Other contestants devoted themselves -to a discussion, principally,
of the lack of an esprit de corps
among the Hopkins students, but
did not advance practical suggestions comparable to Feise's.
The winner is a junior in the College and has been quite active in
extra-curricular work. He was recently a candidate for president of
the Y. M. C. A. Cabinet, and has
taken a leading part in the work of
groups on the campus that are interested in social problems.
This is the third contest of its
kind that has been sponsored by the
0. D. K.*in the past four years.
The previous two, in 1931 and 1933,
were won by Norman S. Heaney,
who was elected to the fraternity
last Spring and is now its vice-president.

Science Academy
Ask $15,000 For
Next Three Years
Fifteen thousand dollars is the
sum needed by the Maryland Academy of Sciences if the fifty-yearold institution is not to close its
doors.
Dr. E. A. Andrews, professor of
zoology at the University and a
member of the academy's scientific
council, expressed the opinion of
many of Baltimore's scientists when
he said that the city needs a museum of natural history to play its
important part in the life of the
community.
A committee of one hundred
members of the academy is attempting, this week, to secure the needed
sum by donations. The money will
be used to support the institution
for three years, at the end of which
time Director Woodfield believes
the academy will be on a self-supporting basis.

Robert Henry Levi, latest addition to the Hopkins lacrosse team,
was born in Baltimore on March 27,
1915. He received his primary and
high .school education in this city.
At high school, Baltimore City
College, Bob first showed the makings of a lacrosse player. For four
successive years he played under
the tuelage of City's coach, Herman Epstein. In his last year at,
City Levi captained the lacrosse
team which won the state championship.
Veteran Attackman

As he was preparing to enter
Hopkins with advanced standing,
Levi had to limit his extra-curricular activity to lacrosse. Bob entered the School of Business
Economics this past fall but became
sick with an attack of appendicitis
at the end of the first term.
Despite the fact that he has been
handicapped as a result of an operation, he has made an excellent
showing on the Blue Jay lacrosse
team, having played in every game
of the season. His position on the
varsity is second attack.

SIZE OF PIGSKIN CHANGED
Football For'College Games Next Fall. To Be Smaller
Following the trend of the
times, the national rules committee on the game of football has
announced, through its secretary,
William S. Langford, a change in
the specifications of the football
for the 1934 season, which will decrease the circumference and
make it easier to handle and forward pass.
The short axis circumference
has been reduced from the old
measurement range of 22 by 222
inches to 214 by 21%. No change
was made in the other specifications as to weight, air pressure,
general shape, or the long axis
circumference.

Football being one of the games
with an almost universal appeal,
the sport is spreading to all parts
of the world, and the name of the
game itself is becoming a worldwide word.
The French play "football,"
and Spanish and South American
countries call it "el futbol," which
is near enough. The German "outside" wing man scores a "goal" in
football, he plays for his "team"
and does his training if his club
is playing for a "cup." And the
game itself, as in France, is "football."
Players in France, Germany,
and Italy are all penalized by the
referee if they have committed a
"foul." In fact, no footballer need
worry about being misunderstood
anywhere in the world. "Goal,"
"offside," and "center" are practically universal words today.

The All-Union Soviet of Students, whose headquarters are in
Moscow, has addressed an official
invitation to American students to
attend a special international session of the Moscow University
Summer School, beginning July 21.
The invitation was sent to the Institute of International Education
2 West 45th Street, New York.
The Summer School, under the
auspices of the Anglo-American Institute of the First Moscow University, will last six weeks. Lectures and instruction will be in
English, and will be given by a faculty of the foremost Soviet professors and specialists.
The purpose of the school is to
afford visiting students a clear conception of Soviet achievements in
cultural and scientific fields since
the 1917 revolution. Visitors will
be offered a wide program of social,
cultural and sp' ort activities

to award the prize in the field of

instructor in English in the College
of Arts and Sciences.
The prizes, which consist of
medals of honor, are awarded each
year by the Baltimore Advertising
Club to Baltimore, men who have
made outstanding contributions in
their fields .

Science Academy
Ask $15,000 For
Next Three Years
Fifteen thousand dollars is the
sum needed by the Maryland Academy of Sciences if the fifty-yearold institution is not to close its
doors.
Dr. E. A. Andrews, professor of
zoology at the University and a
member of the academy's scientific
council, expressed the opinion of
many of Baltimore's scientists when
he said that the city needs a museum of natural history to play its
important part in the life of the
community.
A committee of one hundred
members of the academy is attempting, this week, to secure the needed
sum by donations. The money will
be used to support the institution
for three years, at the end of which
time Director Woodfield believes
the academy will be on a self-supporting basis.
